description: From an Algonquian language; compare Abenaki sôgmô, sôgemô (“chief”), Mi'kmaq saqamaw (“chief”), and Penobscot sagama, sagema, sagemo, sangemo (“chief”), all ultimately from Proto-Algonquian *sa·kima·wa (“male chief”). Doublet of sachem.

entries.meaning: A chief of one or several Native American tribe(s), especially of the Algonquians. [from early 17th c.]
(informal, archaic) An eminent member of a group, or an eminent person in society.
(politics) A high-ranking officer of the Tammany Hall political organization responsible for taking care of its property.
